title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: At the first glance I knew my man for that soldier of Gilbert's, JanHamman, the Hollander, whom already thrice I had met, once in the AlphenRoad, once at the joining of the Cor Water with Tweed, and once at thecaves of the Cor, when so many of His Majesty's servants went to theiraccount.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: The cave of the Cor Water was no more.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: And this is why at this day there is no cave at the Cor Water, nothingbut the bare side of a hill strewn with stones.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: They were part of my cousin's company, and one I recognised asmy old friend Jan Hamman of the Alphen Road and the Cor Water.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Nowhere had I been wise I should at once have gone down the last-named tothe upper waters of Tweed near the village of Tweedsmuir, whence I mighthave come without danger to the wilder hills and the Cor Waterhiding-place.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Soas I tramped through the meadows and leaped the brooks, it was with asad heart, and my whole mind was taken up in conjuring back the pleasanthours I had spent in my lady's company, the old frolics in the wood ofDawyck, the beginnings of our love-making, even the ride hither from theCor Water.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Now I, who had just come from the folk of the Cor Water, had no suchdread of the hillmen, but I forebore to say it.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: Here we halted and suffered our horses to graze,while we partook of some of the food which the folk of the Cor Water hadsent with us.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I knew that the two dragoons had ridden straight down the Cor Waterglen, making for the upper vale of Tweed and thence to the Clyde hills.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: She left me to go out from the little glen, which was theentrance to the cave, into the wider dale of the Cor Water, which ranshallow between lone green braes.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: I had heard of the place before, and knew it for theCor Water, a stream famous for trout, and at this time, no less renownedamong the hillmen as a hiding-place.

title: John Burnet of Barns: A Romance
author: Buchan, John
snippet: He purposed that we should go up Tweed to a hiding-place whichhe knew of on the Cor Water, and then make over by the upper waters ofthe Clyde and the Abington moors to the house of Smitwood.
